hints_html:
How can we write solutions in terms of,

\[\begin{aligned} \exp(\lambda_1{t}),\quad\exp(\lambda_2{t})\end{aligned}\]

?
hints_latex:
How can we write solutions in terms of,

\begin{align*}
\exp(\lambda_1{t}),\quad\exp(\lambda_2{t})
\end{align*}?
hints_raw:
How can we write solutions in terms of,

:<math>
\exp(\lambda_1{t}),\quad\exp(\lambda_2{t})
</math>?
question: B 02 (a)
sols_html:
Recall that a solution to

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}'=A\mathbf{y}\end{aligned}\]

with eigenvalues \(\lambda_1\), \(\lambda_2\) and eigenvectors \(\mathbf{k}_1,\mathbf{k}_2\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(t)=c_1\mathbf{k}_1\exp(\lambda_1{t})+c_2\mathbf{k}_2\exp(\lambda_2{t}).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, for this specific example, the solution is,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}(t)=c_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\exp(-t) + c_2 \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Recall that a solution to

:<math>
\mathbf{y}'=A\mathbf{y}
</math>

with eigenvalues <math>\lambda_1</math>, <math>\lambda_2</math> and eigenvectors <math>\mathbf{k}_1,\mathbf{k}_2</math> is

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(t)=c_1\mathbf{k}_1\exp(\lambda_1{t})+c_2\mathbf{k}_2\exp(\lambda_2{t}).
</math>

Therefore, for this specific example, the solution is,

:<math>
\mathbf{y}(t)=c_1
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-t)
+ c_2
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}\exp(-2t).
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the differential equation system

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}'=A\mathbf{y}\end{aligned}\]

where A has eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=-1\) and \(\lambda_2=-2\) with corresponding eigenvectors

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{k}_1= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix},\qquad \mathbf{k}_2= \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

What is the general solution of the system of differential equations?
statement_raw:
Consider the differential equation system

:<math>
\mathbf{y}'=A\mathbf{y}
</math>

where A has eigenvalues <math>\lambda_1=-1</math> and <math>\lambda_2=-2</math> with corresponding eigenvectors

:<math>
\begin{align}
\mathbf{k}_1=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2
\end{bmatrix},\qquad
\mathbf{k}_2=
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}.
\end{align}
</math>

What is the general solution of the system of differential equations?
